captions.text: We've been teaching in Korea now for over two years
and we really, really love it.  Now, what I believe
as a teacher is that teaching in the classroom is not
What's also very important, if not just as important,
is bonding with your students outside of the classroom, and
it's what makes teaching in Korea so enjoyable for us.
Now, over the past two years I've compiled a small video
of all the special moments I've had with my students
and I put it together for you today.
This video's really special to me, so

comments.text: FUN!﻿

That kid wearing the shirt "I'm so fucking future" made me laugh so hard. 
If kids in the states wore shirts like that they would get in so much 
trouble. (Well at all the schools I went to anyways.) One of the schools I 
went to, they sent a guy home for having a chick in a bikini on his shirt 
because it was offensive and too sexual, and another student was sent home 
for having random words (not bad words) in graffiti on his shirt but they 
claimed it was "gang related" and "not appropriate" for school. But that 
just made my day. xD﻿

comments.author: Emily Vang

comments.text:
+SURVIV4R Many Koreans don't come home until 9 or 10 because of hagwon 
which is called a tutoring school but is basically just more school. I'm 
Korean but I live in America now, but I know my cousins and other teens 
back in Korea go to school for about 15-16 hours a day. It's not generally 
just for "hard workers" but most students due to the harsh education system 
we have there.
comments.author: Aspen Ahraea Cho

comments.text:
+SURVIV4R School starts at like 7 or 8 am and ends at 3 pm, but they have 
to stay later to around 9, or even midnight for other things like after 
school classes, self studying, etc. Overall, it's 12-17 hrs.

This all happens outside the home btw. What I described was high school 
life and it's not likely someone younger than that age does this.
comments.author: BLS.

comments.text:
They stay with the same classmates for like 17 hrs a day so they're almost 
family. Teachers won't snitch on you for something as trivial as running as 
long as you're safe. Of course it's a double edged sword since it's harsher 
on the "outcasts" though...
comments.author: BLS.

comments.text: Same in England in all the schools I've been to

comments.author: shineunri .j

comments.text:
Well... I'm studying Pedagogy in English at university, so hopefully, I'll 
be an English teacher in the future... Notice that I'm just 19 and I 
graduated from highschool in 2012. A few hours ago I had a conversation 
with my parents about withdrawing the career to get a translation degree 
somewhere else. I've been to classrooms and I've had students as well 
because I'm a private English teacher, but I've been seriously over 
thinking about it because I'm still young and highschoolers are like... My 
age? I don't know, but I feel like that. I was seriously thinking of 
withdrawing the career, but now that I watched this video... Wow. I'm 
thankful I watched it, because it reminded me of why I wanted to become a 
teacher.
My little brother has Asperger, and he's really clever and has a really 
unique personality, but he doesn't do well on his exams, because he has a 
type of nervous anxiety and he forgets all he learned when sitting an exam, 
he also has ADHD which it can't be treated by taking pills.

My reason of why I want to become a teacher is to help those guys like my 
brother, because they must be valuable in whatever they want to.

I also experienced a student being expelled during my practicum in a public 
school because of his bad behaviour, and I really had hopes of him doing 
well since he acted so nice around me and started learning English when I 
came in (English is quite horrible in public schools here.), but they 
didn't even gave him a chance. 
I want to save kids like him, because I know one by one we can make a 
change.
Thank you, Simon and Martina. <3
Love from Chile.﻿
comments.author: Paulina Gnecco

comments.text: Verry emotional﻿

comments.author: Taylor Machado

comments.text:
Hey Simon. I just wanted wanted you to know that I saw this video shortly 
after it came out a few years ago, and it's the reason why I decided to 
become a teacher. Now, I still have a year left of high school, but I can't 
go a day without thinking what it'll be like when I do start teaching on 
down the road. I plan on teaching (hopefully) high school English in either 
Korea or Japan, and I've been a huge Nasty for at least three or four years 
now. I just wanted to say thanks for kick starting my dream into action, 
and that you guys are the bomb-dot-diggity-com.﻿

comments.author: TheDarkenedBride

comments.text:
You will find that to teach English in Japan you usually need a couple of 
years experience of teaching in another country. This is why so many 
English speaking teachers start of in Korea. Many schools and hogwans are 
now employing native Koreans to teach English, so positions for foreign 
teachers are lower than even about 5 years ago. But don`t give up on your 
dream. You will achieve it.

comments.text:
High school in the States is like 7 hours or so shuffling through classes 
with different people in them. High school in Korea effectively lasts for 
17 hours since you stay with your homeroom classmates all day and stay 
after with them. It's like second nature to act as a family.

really wish people weren't so stereotypical here.
